ques: The _______ of this book is blue.
The _______ of this table is round.
The _______ of this suitcase is 20 lbs.
This suitcase is a small _______
This window is high. Its _______ is three feet.
This is a wide street. Its _______ is 36 feet.
This _______ feels soft.
This suitcase is awfully heavy. It is not _______
This table is pretty small. It is not _______
This material feels fairly soft. It is not _______
Jones Boulevard is very wide. It is not _______
The window was wet. It was not _______
These walls are two feet thick. They are not _______
This street is very long. It is not _______
This is a thin book. It is not _______
This is a narrow window. It is not _______
This is a light briefcase. It is not _______
This is a hard bed. It is not _______
This street is dry. It is not _______
This table is short. It is not _______
_______ is that wall? It is three feet thick.
_______ of that street? It is 36 feet wide.
_______ is this book than that one? They are the same weight.
_______ is your book? It is red and blue.
_______ are your suitcases? One is small and the other is medium.
_______ is that table? It is round.
_______ of that material? It is three yards long.
_______ is John? His height is exactly six feet.
How many pounds do you _______ ?
I don’t know how many pounds I _______
John _______ one hundred and fifty pounds.
You _______ your suitcase to see what size it is.
My mother _______ the windows to see how wide they are.
I _______ heavier than my sister.
These windows _______ wider than those.
Dogs _______ smaller than elephants.
How much does that typewriter _______ ?
They are _______ the windows now to see how high they are.
I am _______ my suitcase to see what its weight is.
The boulevard _______ only three miles long.
That man is _______ the boulevard now to see what its width is.
That street _______ longer than this one.
Will you _______ the length of this material for me, please?
Please ask John to _______ the lights _______ It’s dark in here.
_______ your books _______ on the table, please.
_______ my coat _______ in the closet, will you?
Please don’t _______ me, I'll be busy all afternoon.
Would you mind _______ a favor _______ me?
Would you please _______ those cups and saucers from the table?
I Would you mind _______ these books _______ to the library?
Tell him to _______ the lights _______ when he goes to bed.
Which _______ is it to the post office?
Go _______ for three blocks.
How _______ is it to the hotel?
Turn left and you can’t _______ it.
The theater is _______ the street.
The airport is a _______ from here.
The bank is five _______ from the church.
Excuse me, is this seat _______ ?
I should turn _______ at this corner.
The house is around the _______
I grew _______ in a small country town.
There used to be a grocery store _______ the corner.
A young married couple moved _______ next door.
We bought the new house two blocks _______ you.
He lived in Texas _______ he was seventeen.
An elderly man rented the house _______ us.
I spent my childhood _______ a farm.
Many of those houses have been built _______ the last ten years.
The movie theater is _______ the street from me.
(leave)
I _______ the house at 8:00 every day. (leave)
I _______ the house at 8:00 tomorrow. (leave)
I _______ to work last week. (go)
I _______ to work today. (go)
I _______ to work tomorrow morning. (go)
I _______ late yesterday. (be)
If I don’t hurry, I _______ late today. (be)
John _______ in the middle of last night. (wake up)
I _______ television last Saturday, (watch)
I _______ television next Tuesday morning. (watch)
Yesterday it _______ all night. (hailed, hail)
It’s _______ now. (snow, snowing)
The weather’s getting _______ (hotter, more hotter)
Is it _______? (rain, raining)
The weather was very _______ (nicer, nice)
I'll probably be _______ all afternoon. (drizzle, drizzling)
There’s a strong _______ this evening. (wind, windy)
The weather will be _______ tomorrow. (cloudy, clouds)
Has it _______ yet? (clearing up, cleared up)
The weather was _______ last week. (terribly, terrible)
I _______ feel well today. (doesn’t, don’t, am not)
My headache _______ gone. (are, do, is)
My sister _______ a fever. (have, has, makes)
My arm _______ (hurt, hurts, do hurt)
Did you _______ your arm? (broke, breaks, break)
I _______ and fell down. (slip, slips, slipped)
She often _______ and falls. (slip, slips, slipped)
Mary _______ you'll feel better soon. (hope, hopes, hopes to)
My leg _______ bleeding. (are, is, aren’t)
Have you ever _______ your leg? (break, broke, broken)
I _______ go with her. (hope to, hopes to, hopes)
I've _______ a pain in my back. (get, got, getting)
You'd _______ go see a doctor. (good, better, well)
Your thumb is _______ (swells, swell, swollen)
My friend slipped and _______ down the stairs.
His leg was _______ and _______
I told him he _______ see a doctor.
He said to the doctor, “My leg _______ very much.”
He said to the doctor, “My leg _______ very much.”
He feels better today, but he still has a _______ in his leg.
I _______ of bed at 7 a.m.
After _______, I take a shower.
After that, I _______ my clothes.
Before I leave the house, I _______ my brother.
When he is dressed, we _______ the kitchen for breakfast.
At bedtime, I _______ my clothes and put on my pajamas.
After that, I go upstairs and _______ bed.
I usually _______ right _______ to sleep.
I take off _______ clothes before I go to bed.
My little brother tried to button _______ own shirt.
He can’t dress _______ yet.
She usually combs _______ own hair.
She still cannot bathe _______
The children tried to put their jackets on _______
You can dress _______ , can’t you?
In the morning the children took off _______ own pajamas.
Do you eat _______ breakfast in the dining room?
After the boys get up, _______ shave and brush their teeth.
John goes downstairs where _______ fixes breakfast.
After John and I get dressed, _______ eat breakfast together in the kitchen.
Then _______ go back upstairs to wake up my sister.
I help her get dressed because _______ is still too young to dress herself.
You help your little brother, don’t _______ ?
Give me your opinion. I really want to know your _______
We prefer sunshine. We _______ hot weather best.
I think finishing work early before a holiday is an excellent idea. In my opinion, that will be _______
I think John is mistaken about that. Do you also believe he is _______?
Your conclusion is absolutely right about that. I know you are _______
Of course I will give you my frank opinion. _______ , I will be honest with you.
explanation: "Color" refers to the hue or shade of an object. In this context, the statement is about the blue color of the book.
"Shape" refers to the form or outline of an object. In this context, the table is described as round, which is a shape.
"Weight" refers to how heavy an object is. In this context, the suitcase weighs 20 pounds.
"Size" refers to the dimensions or magnitude of an object. In this context, the suitcase is small in size.
"Height" refers to the measurement from the base to the top of an object. In this context, the window's height is three feet.
"Width" refers to the measurement from side to side. In this context, the street's width is 36 feet.
"Material" refers to the substance from which an object is made. In this context, the material feels soft.
"Light" is the opposite of heavy. In this context, the suitcase being heavy means it is not light.
"Large" is the opposite of small. In this context, the table being small means it is not large.
"Hard" is the opposite of soft. In this context, the material being soft means it is not hard.
"Narrow" is the opposite of wide. In this context, the boulevard being wide means it is not narrow.
"Dry" is the opposite of wet. In this context, the window being wet means it is not dry.
"Thin" is the opposite of thick. In this context, the walls being thick means they are not thin.
"Short" is the opposite of long. In this context, the street being long means it is not short.
"Thick" is the opposite of thin. In this context, the book being thin means it is not thick.
"Wide" is the opposite of narrow. In this context, the window being narrow means it is not wide.
"Heavy" is the opposite of light. In this context, the briefcase being light means it is not heavy.
"Soft" is the opposite of hard. In this context, the bed being hard means it is not soft.
"Wet" is the opposite of dry. In this context, the street being dry means it is not wet.
"Long" is the opposite of short. In this context, the table being short means it is not long.
"How thick" is the correct question to ask about the measurement of the wall's thickness. The answer indicates the thickness of the wall.
"What is the width" is the correct question to ask about the measurement of the street's width. The answer indicates the width of the street.
"How much heavier" is the correct question to ask about the weight comparison between two objects. The context specifies that the books are the same weight.
"What color" is the correct question to ask about the color of the book. The answer indicates the colors red and blue.
"What sizes" is the correct question to ask about the sizes of the suitcases. The answer indicates one is small and the other is medium.
"What shape" is the correct question to ask about the form of the table. The answer indicates that the table is round.
"What is the length" is the correct question to ask about the measurement of the material's length. The answer indicates it is three yards long.
"How tall" is the correct question to ask about the height of a person. The answer indicates John's height is six feet.
"Weigh" is the correct verb to use when asking about someone's weight. The question is asking for the weight in pounds.
"Weigh" is the correct verb to use when talking about one's own weight. The statement indicates uncertainty about the weight.
"Weighs" is the correct verb to use when stating someone's weight. The sentence specifies John's weight.
"Measure" is the correct verb to use when determining the size of an object. The context is about finding out the suitcase's size.
"Measures" is the correct verb to use when determining the width of the windows. The sentence describes an action taken by the mother.
"Am" is the correct verb to use in this context, as it links the subject "I" with the predicate "heavier than my sister."
"Are" is the correct verb to use to indicate the state of the windows. The sentence compares the width of two sets of windows.
"Are" is the correct verb to use to indicate the state of being. The sentence compares the size of dogs and elephants.
"Weigh" is the correct verb to use when asking about the weight of an object. The question is asking for the typewriter's weight.
"Measuring" is the correct verb to use when determining the height of the windows. The sentence describes the action being taken.
"Weighing" is the correct verb to use when determining the weight of an object. The sentence describes the action being taken.
"Is" is the correct verb to use to describe the state of being. The sentence specifies the length of the boulevard.
"Measuring" is the correct verb to use when determining the width of the boulevard. The sentence describes the action being taken by the man.
"Is" is the correct verb to use to describe the state of being. The sentence compares the length of two streets.
"Measure" is the correct verb to use when determining the length of an object. The sentence is a request to measure the material.
"Turn on" means to activate or switch on an electrical appliance. In this context, it means to turn on the lights because it's dark.
"Put down" means to place something in a lower position. In this context, it means to put the books on the table.
"Hang up" means to suspend or hang something. In this context, it means to hang the coat in the closet.
"Wait for" means to remain in expectation of someone or something. In this context, it means not to wait for the person because they will be busy.
"Doing a favor for" means to perform a helpful act for someone. In this context, it means asking someone to do a favor.
"Pick up" means to lift or take something from a surface. In this context, it means to remove the cups and saucers from the table.
"Taking back" means to return something to its original place. In this context, it means returning the books to the library.
"Turn off" means to deactivate or switch off an electrical appliance. In this context, it means to turn off the lights before going to bed.
"Way" refers to the direction or path to a location. In this context, it means asking for the direction to the post office.
"Straight ahead" means to continue in a direct line. In this context, it means to keep going straight for three blocks.
"Far" refers to the distance to a location. In this context, it means asking for the distance to the hotel.
"Miss" means to fail to see or notice something. In this context, it means that if you turn left, you will definitely see it and not miss it.
"Across" means on the other side of something. In this context, it means the theater is on the other side of the street.
"Long drive" refers to a considerable distance to travel by car. In this context, it means the airport is a considerable distance from here.
"Miles" is a unit of distance. In this context, it means the bank is five miles away from the church.
"Taken" means occupied. In this context, it means asking if the seat is already occupied by someone else.
"Right" refers to the direction to turn. In this context, it means to turn right at the corner.
"Corner" refers to the place where two streets meet, indicating that the house is nearby, just around the corner.
"Grew up" is a phrasal verb that means to develop or mature in a particular place. It fits the context of spending one's childhood in a small country town.
"On the corner" means located at the intersection of two streets. It fits the context of where the grocery store was located.
"Moved in" means to begin living in a new place. It fits the context of the couple starting to live next door.
"From" indicates the starting point of measurement. It fits the context of the distance between the new house and "you."
"Until" indicates the end point of a period of time. It fits the context of living in Texas up to the age of seventeen.
"From" indicates the source. It fits the context of renting the house from an elderly man.
"On" is used to indicate location. It fits the context of spending childhood on a farm.
"In" indicates the time period during which something happened. It fits the context of houses being built in the last ten years.
"Up the street" means further along the street in a particular direction. It fits the context of the movie theater's location.
"Left" is the past tense of "leave," fitting the context of an action that happened yesterday.
"Leave" is the present tense, fitting the context of a habitual action that happens every day.
"Will leave" is the future tense, fitting the context of an action that will happen tomorrow.
"Went" is the past tense of "go," fitting the context of an action that happened last week.
"Am going" is the present continuous tense, fitting the context of an action happening today.
"Will go" is the future tense, fitting the context of an action that will happen tomorrow morning.
"Was" is the past tense of "be," fitting the context of an action that happened yesterday.
"Will be" is the future tense, fitting the context of a conditional action that may happen today.
"Wake up" is the base form, but the correct answer should be "woke up" to fit the past tense. The correct form should be reviewed.
"Watched" is the past tense of "watch," fitting the context of an action that happened last Saturday.
"Will watch" is the future tense, fitting the context of an action that will happen next Tuesday morning.
"Hailed" is the past tense of "hail," fitting the context of an action that happened yesterday.
"Snowing" is the present continuous tense, fitting the context of an action that is happening right now.
"Hotter" is the correct comparative form of "hot." "More hotter" is incorrect because "hotter" already implies a comparison.
"Raining" is the present continuous form, fitting the context of asking about the current weather condition.
"Nice" is the correct adjective to describe the weather. "Nicer" is comparative and "nicely" is an adverb, neither of which fit this context.
"Drizzling" is the present continuous form, fitting the context of an action that will likely happen throughout the afternoon.
"Wind" is the noun that describes the phenomenon. "Windy" is an adjective and does not fit the context of "a strong _______."
"Cloudy" is the adjective that describes the weather condition. "Clouds" is a noun and does not fit this context.
"Cleared up" is the past participle form used in perfect tenses, fitting the context of asking if the action is completed.
"Terrible" is the correct adjective to describe the weather. "Terribly" is an adverb and does not fit this context.
"Don't" is the correct negative form to use with "I." The sentence means "I do not feel well today."
"Is" is the correct verb form to use with the singular subject "headache." The sentence means "My headache is gone."
"Has" is the correct verb form to use with the singular subject "sister." The sentence means "My sister has a fever."
"Hurts" is the correct verb form to use with the singular subject "arm." The sentence means "My arm hurts."
"Break" is the correct base form to use after "Did you." The sentence is asking if the person broke their arm.
"Slipped" is the past tense of "slip," fitting the context of an action that happened in the past.
"Slips" is the correct present tense form to use with the singular subject "She." The sentence describes a habitual action.
"Hopes" is the correct verb form to use with the singular subject "Mary." The sentence means "Mary hopes you'll feel better soon."
"Is" is the correct verb form to use with the singular subject "leg." The sentence means "My leg is bleeding."
"Broken" is the past participle form used with "have" to form the present perfect tense, fitting the context of asking if the action has ever happened.
"Hope to" is the correct form to use with "I" to express a desire to do something in the future.
"Got" is the past participle form used with "have" to form the present perfect tense, fitting the context of describing a condition that exists.
"Better" is the correct form to use after "you'd" (short for "you had") to give advice, meaning it would be advisable to see a doctor.
"Swollen" is the past participle form used to describe the state of the thumb. It fits the context of describing a condition.
"Fell" is the past tense of "fall," fitting the context of an action that happened in the past.
"Swollen" and "bleeding" are adjectives describing the condition of his leg. They fit the context of an injury.
"Ought to" is a modal verb phrase used to give advice, meaning he should see a doctor.
"Hurts" is the present tense form of "hurt," fitting the context of describing ongoing pain.
This sentence seems to repeat the previous one, and "hurts" would be the correct answer, but the provided option doesn't match.
"Pain" is the correct noun to describe a feeling of discomfort or soreness, fitting the context of an injury.
"Get out" is a phrasal verb meaning to leave a bed. It fits the context of describing a morning routine.
"Getting up" is a gerund phrase describing the action before taking a shower.
"Put on" is a phrasal verb meaning to dress in clothes. It fits the context of describing a routine.
"Wake up" is a phrasal verb meaning to awaken someone. It fits the context of describing a morning routine.
"Go into" is a phrasal verb meaning to enter a place. It fits the context of describing a routine.
"Take off" is a phrasal verb meaning to remove clothes. It fits the context of describing a bedtime routine.
"Get into" is a phrasal verb meaning to lie down in bed. It fits the context of describing a bedtime routine.
"Go off" is a phrasal verb meaning to fall asleep quickly. It fits the context of describing a bedtime routine.
"My" is the correct possessive adjective to use with "clothes." The sentence describes a personal action before bedtime.
"His" is the correct possessive pronoun to match "little brother" and "shirt." The sentence means that the brother tried to button his own shirt.
"Himself" is the correct reflexive pronoun to match "he." The sentence means he cannot dress himself yet.
"Her" is the correct possessive pronoun to match "she." The sentence means she usually combs her own hair.
"Herself" is the correct reflexive pronoun to match "she." The sentence means she still cannot bathe herself.
"Themselves" is the correct reflexive pronoun to match "the children." The sentence means the children tried to put their jackets on themselves.
"Yourself" is the correct reflexive pronoun to match "you." The sentence means you can dress yourself.
"Their" is the correct possessive pronoun to match "the children." The sentence means the children took off their own pajamas.
"Your" is the correct possessive pronoun to match "you." The sentence means do you eat your breakfast in the dining room.
"They" is the correct subject pronoun to match "the boys." The sentence means after the boys get up, they shave and brush their teeth.
"He" is the correct subject pronoun to match "John." The sentence means John goes downstairs where he fixes breakfast.
"We" is the correct subject pronoun to match "John and I." The sentence means after John and I get dressed, we eat breakfast together in the kitchen.
"I" is the correct subject pronoun to match the speaker. The sentence means then I go back upstairs to wake up my sister.
"She" is the correct subject pronoun to match "her." The sentence means I help her get dressed because she is still too young to dress herself.
"You" is the correct pronoun to match the subject in a tag question. The sentence means you help your little brother, don’t you?
"Judgment" is the correct noun meaning an opinion or conclusion. The sentence means I really want to know your judgment.
"Like" is the correct verb meaning to enjoy or prefer. The sentence means we like hot weather best.
"Wonderful" is the correct adjective meaning very good. The sentence means in my opinion, that will be wonderful.
"Wrong" is the correct adjective meaning not correct. The sentence means do you also believe he is wrong?
"Correct" is the correct adjective meaning accurate. The sentence means I know you are correct.
"Naturally" is the correct adverb meaning in a normal or expected way. The sentence means naturally, I will be honest with you.
